RE: American Power Act

I have not had the chance to read the full bill since it will not be made public until tomorrow. Nevertheless, I have a strong opinion to express regarding some of the possible components revealed in the media.

I unequivocally oppose any subsidies or incentives that would encourage offshore drilling. As a resident of Sarasota, Florida, I appreciate the beauty and the economic benefits of our beaches. The current oil spill off the Louisiana coast threatens all shorelines along the Gulf of Mexico.

But the threat doesn’t stop there. If the oil reaches the Gulf Loop Current, it could make its way through the Florida Straits to the Atlantic Ocean and to the Gulf Stream Current. We could end up sharing bits of our Gulf catastrophy with the east coast of the U.S. The BP oil spill, combined with the power of winds and currents should make it obvious that a state’s ability to prevent offshore drilling within 75 miles is no protection at all!

Given the inevitable power of the oil companies, I at least urge that no further offshore drilling be considered until those oil companies have provided convincing scientifically sound means of containing any future spills. Offshore platforms have existed since 1947. How can we have pursued this technology for 63 years without having demanded effective containment procedures?
drill, baby spill?

The highest price will be paid by the Wampanoag, whose sacred grounds and waters will be over-run with heavy machinery digging, dredging, and trenching -- then 130 wind turbines and an electrical service platform housing tens of thousands of gallons of fuel, hydraulic fluid, and greases. There is no dollar amount to remedy ecocide and ethnocide.

What ever happened to calling a halt and conducting an auction to rebalance supply and demand? Other exchanges know to listen for -- and obey -- halts. Instead, the NYSE went slow -- causing other exchanges to assume (sensibly) that they were having systems problems.

We already have the solution to this. Best part: the NYSE has such a system in place... at Euronext, their European stock exchanges group. I guess the merger integration has been mostly one-way!

I have high hope when our Congress sets its foot on the financial reform last year. But what do we have today?

1) Bailout fund – denied.
2) TBTF – abstain.
3) CFPA – downsized.
4) Derivatives – business as usual – grandfathered-in.
5) Flash/program trading – clueless.

Maybe we should just re-instate the Glass Steagall.

Let’s see;
1) Dood/Shelby rules – never tested – years of success – none.
2) Volker Rules – never tested – years of success – none.
3) Glass Steagall – tested – years of success – over three decades.

What should be our (taxpayers) choice?

I think Prof. Alan Blinder was right - the one chance of lifetime for our financial reform is gone.

I appreciate the simplified summary and agree with the points laid out in this article.

The failure of the Kaufman-Broun SAFE Banking act (to break up big banks that have grown reduculusly over years of deregulation so they wouldn't pose a risk where they would be given another bailout next time a bet went bad) was a huge disappointment. All derivitieves need to be traded on an open clearinghouse, instead of a "shadow banking system" where they can conceal fraud daily that is now estimated 6 times larger then the real US economy. Banks also have no business gamblisg (I mean investing) on derivitive exchanges with FDIC insured funds. We did not have frequent financial crisises when banking was simply taking deposits and making loans, all the gambling can happen at hedge funds whose failure simply results in then going under.

1.Walter J Smith: I do disagree with some of your points. Blance Lincoln's ammendment to force banks to get rid of proprietary trading units is currently the strongest language aimed at eliminating these FDIC insures reckless bets. You asked for naming of names, here's a good article descibing what the major political players are fighting for or agaisnt: http://www.tnr.com...

Folks can call it populist policy all they want, but that is also called progressive policy.  Our economy should serve all of us fairly.  Enough folks are angry AND informed enough to see sense in this policy.  It's enough for me.  I've been demanding it for three years.

the governance of the exchanges is a joke. There should be no “for profit” exchange entities (I don’t know whether CBOT is or not) nor should they pay ~ $100M salaries like we learned about Grosso at NYSE. Anyone that can't see limiting the total share of volume of any one trader is a CRITICAL function of any well-run exchange is not aspiring to create a well-functioning market. 9% of trading volume over a 20 minute period for a high volume product? We have rules about making SEC filings when their holdings are > 15% (maybe even less) so that traders can’t manipulate the markets a the expense of shareholders – well 9% of trading volume in 20 MINUTES IS manipulating the markets. Then again these are the same groups that brought us “flash trading” as a product line extension to grow the profits of the exchanges.

We wonder why the top four banks all showed they could reliably make more than $100M per day trading in Q1.....the more I learn about how our markets are run the more ill I get and the more I realize the selfish folks running our financial services industry really are destroying the long term prospects for our economy.

We need to continue to wake up our Congress so that they realize the pattern here: indignant about Grosso, flash trading, happy to allow an unmanaged market to drive volumes, etc. all adds up to not performing the role envisioned by Adam Smith (and many others).

It takes all of my will power to not make a completely inappropriate comment about this guy. I want to, oh how I want to.

Am I wrong to think whatever Ben Roethlisberger did is worse then whatever L.T. did?
He should have done this when Detroit cut him, but regardless, he belongs in the Hockey Hall of Fame as soon as possible.

Please pardon my ignorance but "As far as the riders’ hands are concerned, we keep them down. Personally, I have a couple of fingers from my left hand wrapped around the neckstrap and hold the cross (reigns should always be bridged when riding thoroughbreds in training) with my left hand. My right hand is a little more flexible and usually also carries a stick. Hands stay down and held to the neckstrap to avoid being too heavy on the horse’s mouth.
the last part I can visualize trying to keep soft hands for the mouths of the babies,But are you taking the right hand rein and holding it in your left hand and vice versa? I am just having a hard time visualizing where the reins are going from the snaffle to which hand. I'm sure there is a very simple explanation and I will be smacking my own head when it becomes so obvious, but for now, I'm as confused as one of the baby horses there for the first time out on the track...

Then I'm going to work for the bank, make mine for me, creating as many synthetic CDO's as possible, supporting only GOP PAC's, getting an over-blown house loan, and reading only the WSJ - don't come crying some day that you, your parents or your spouse's parents paid into Social Security and expect anything back; a lot of tax cuts were passed out to the very highest earning people in the history of the human-kind, and a $Trillion in deficit spending was run up by the previous administration, but the biggest budget item/target is the upcoming Social Security expense, so we're gonna cut it because it's easy.

California's budget crisis could cost nearly 27,000 teachers their jobs this year.
State school districts had issued 26,905 pink slips to teachers and other school employees by next Monday, the legal deadline for districts to send preliminary layoff notices.

Quote: 'Military spending, for instance, is now less than 5 percent of gross domestic product.'

Express these amounts as portions of the federal budget, not percentages of the nation's GDP. Then you'll see how big they really are.

Nick Lidstrom was NOT the first European-born captain of an NHL team. There were others before him, among them Jaromir Jagr with the Pens and Caps. Lidstrom WAS the first European-born captain of a Stanley-Cup winning team.

NYT editor -- Thanks. Fixed.

Mr. Obama and Mr.Karzai, take two...opposites that do not attract each other! Dislike each other might be more realistic. But they have to stick together, or both risk become losers of the Afghan war quagmire.

The administration's less certain policy in Afghanistan is actually simpler: Obama wants to play tough - rather than risk the label of "a softie" in his 2012 re-election. He knows the U.S. will lose the war, but he doesn't want it to happen before 2012. His policy, therefore: Just keep the ball rolling until then!

Is Karzai surrounded by corrupt cronies? Certainly. Can he get rid of them? No way! He will be assassinated!

1000 State Department employees to supervise U.S. Aid allocation? It is vain. Karzai's corrupt ministers and bureaucrats get all of it! I have seen Afghan villagers and elders telling BBC and Al Jazeera reporters they have gotten nothing - after 9 years of U.S. funding.
After Karzai's corrupt circle, maybe Indian contractors, and Pakistani
intermediaries get the rest. The Afghan rural population support the
Taliban because most of the U.S. money is spend in Kabul, where the villagers believe politicians and their cousins, wardlord connected bureaucrats, contractors, prostitutes, and foreigners
live in splendor, but the villagers get only air-strikes, and doors broken down at night by U.S. special forces, but have not seen any benefit during the 9 years of this supposed democratic development of their country.

Mr. Obama and Mr. Karzai, take two... Sure. One, Karzai,interested only to stay in power with his corrupt allies, enrich themselves, and retire in Saudi Arabia or Great Britain when the Taliban take over. The
second, Obama, struggles to prevent a Taliban takeover before his 2012
re-election. Karzai and Obama, therefore, have both self-serving interests to discuss and to protect, but those interests are neither of the Afghan, nor of the American people. Nikos Retsos, retired professor

This is the first time President Obama reminded me of former President George W. Bush.  It appeared Obama was saying things he didn't want to say. America is in a complicated situation with Afghanistan.  We are completely entangled in that country.   And if we don't figure a way out soon the quicksand will turn into quick drying cement.

"We hope all the hospitality does not leave President Karzai thinking he’s off the hook. We assume Mr. Obama was a bit blunter in private. We hope Mr. Obama is also having tough discussions with his own team."

Or what, exactly?

"Until the government can been seen providing minimal security, jobs, water and electricity, Afghans are unlikely to take the risk of rejecting the Taliban."

I would like to point out that not all Afghans are "unlikely to take the risk of rejecting the Taliban." The Taliban are Pashtuns and they only find support among other Pashtuns.

The Afghans who are not Pashtuns, for example the Hazaras (whom the Taliban tried to exterminate in the nineties), the Uzbeks, the Tajiks and the Turkmen, have always and will always reject the Taliban.

These were the people who supported the Northern Alliance. They fought the Taliban all through the nineties, and they were still fighting the Taliban when our troops arrived after 9/11.

Please get your terminology straight. Afghanistan is a complex, multicultural society. Taliban support comes only from their own ethnic group, and you need to make this clear in your future reporting.
The result of the Democrat primary is irrelevant.  Pennsylvania, like many other states , will be sending a real Republican to D.C. as a result of November's election.

You seem to have a theme going here, Gail. Yesterday in your conversation with David Brooks, you suggested limited terms for Supreme Court Justices. Now you don't seem to think octogenarians should automatically be returned to elected office. I'm with you.

The original idea (I'm such an "originalist"!) for members of the House of Representatives was that they should be citizen-legislators who had real careers back home & just served their country for a few years -- kinda like the draft, I guess -- before returning to their actual jobs.

Sure, Senators were supposed to be solons of sorts, but the Founding Fathers found good reason not to elect them for life (although James Madison originally thought that, too, would be a swell idea). Maybe, before the days when corporations became people -- that is, way last year -- it would have been all right to keep these wise old Byrds (nothing personal, Harry) around till they croaked on the Senate floor. But now the main qualification for public office is the ability to raise funds. Does anybody think a talent for fund-raising is actually proof of legislative ability?

For a while there, the U.S. Congress had less turnover than the Soviet Politburo. (Really, it did.) The American people, in their perverse wisdom, have lately decided to change that. Bob Bennett got all teary-eyed when he lost his job at 76. He was pretty much the only one. It isn't that incumbents are necessarily bad. For a Republican (okay, he's a Democrat now), I found Specter sort of lovable in his uniquely irascible way. But I still think Pennsylvanians should give him a chance to spend more time with his great-grandchildren or his dog or whoever. And I would be the first one to propose an earmark for a John McCain Retirement Fund.

You old boys are really, really not the only ones capable of running the country. Give some of those 50-year-old kids a chance to muck things up. And go gracefully. Don't cry.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

Taking down entrenched incumbents is not necessarily a bad thing. Change can be cathartic if it's positive, and even moderate change can have a therapeutic effect. But the kind of change being demanded by Teabaggers more often than not seems to require therapy.

Bob Bennett, recently ousted in Utah, related the story of voters who wanted him gone because he actually delivered the goods to their state. They saw that as some kind of treason. Another voter decided against him because he didn't "love the Constitution enough". No doubt they were referring to specific parts of the Constitution, such as the second and tenth amendments.

It remains to be seen whether the Teabaggers offer any solutions other than change because they say so. For now, they are haters in need of a hard target. Until it becomes legal to hunt incumbents they'll have to be satisfied with the occasional victory over the Bob Bennetts.

As for some kind of larger plan or anything resembling a thoughtful, coordinated effort at making the country a better place (other than getting rid of all those who don't goose-step along with them), since there doesn't seem to be any such thing in the near future, the rest of us will just have to wait until they crash in burn in all their resplendent hatred and vitriol.

One does wonder where all this love of the Constitution was when it was being shredded and routinely defiled by Bush, Cheney, and their merry band of neo-con war criminals. Last I looked, spying on Americans, lying to start wars, stealing elections, willfully ignoring civil liberties--none of those things were constitutional.

Just saying....

The best I can figure, the last time the place where I live elected a Republican Congressman, the nation was also electing Warren G. Harding, and that Congressman didn't last in office as long as Harding.  There ought to be a new rule that says when a party has continually held a certain elective seat for a century or two, the other guys ought to get a free pass for one election simply for variety's sake. :)
